summary: This is an email chain from November 26, 2021, containing press guidance from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the upcoming trial of Ghislaine Maxwell. It clarifies that witnesses will testify under pseudonyms, provides logistical details for the final pretrial conference, and includes a query from a journalist about identifying a witness who had previously waived anonymity.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant charged with conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein to entice minors to travel to engage in criminal sexual activity. Her trial is the subject of the press guidance.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the individual with whom Ghislaine Maxwell conspired to commit the alleged crimes.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge over the case U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell, scheduled to hold the final pretrial conference.

persons.name: Nicholas Biase
persons.context: Author of the official SDNY press guidance email, providing instructions to media regarding witness anonymity and trial logistics.

persons.name: Jim Margolin
persons.context: Colleague of Nicholas Biase, copied on the email for media to contact regarding access to government exhibits.

persons.name: Dipesh Gadher
persons.context: Reporter for The Sunday Times who emails to ask for clarification on whether he can identify a witness by name given a previous waiver of anonymity.

connections.description: Maxwell is charged with conspiring with Epstein to entice minors to travel to engage in criminal sexual activity.
Both are part of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY, working together on press guidance for the Maxwell trial.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: SDNY Press Guidance Issued
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York issues press guidance regarding the upcoming Ghislaine Maxwell trial, detailing witness pseudonym protocols and media logistics.

events.title: Final Pretrial Conference
events.description: Scheduled final pretrial conference for U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell before Judge Alison Nathan.

locations: 40 Foley Square, Courtroom 318 (Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse, New York, NY)
1 London Bridge Street, London SE1 9GF (The Sunday Times office)
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office confirms that several government witnesses in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial will testify using a pseudonym or first name, as ordered by the court to protect victims describing alleged sexual abuse.
A journalist inquires about identifying a specific witness by name, noting the witness had previously waived her right to anonymity and testified under her own name at prior bail hearings.
The press guidance stresses that media should not identify victim or witness pseudonyms, regardless of any previous identifications or waivers.
The document outlines the logistical setup for the trial, including overflow courtrooms and exclusive access to government exhibits via a secure file share.
